biblStruct.note: In this article, Marlene Allen's piece works to connect CaShawn Thompson's 2013 phrase "Black girl magic" to the Black Panther film. She describes the Black excellence of the women in the film as "Black women magic". She goes into great detail when describing each of the Black actress's role and explains why they emulate "Black women magic". Allen's emphasis on amplififying the importance of these Black women characters in the film is vital to our project considering there has been a lot of attention paid to amplifying the voices of Black women and men who have contributed to the Black Panther conversation.

projectDesc.p: This project seeks to identify, collect, preserve, and analyze FREEDOM discourse, as constituted and argued by Black users online. Directed by Dr. Jessica H. Lu, this project is currently being advanced by several undergraduate students at the University of Maryland, College Park: Sophia Crooks, Kayla Graham, Kaanita Iyer, Ariana Lawson, Alice Liu, and Courtney Richardson.

person.note: Camille Friend plays an important part in the Black Panther movie as she oversaw majority of the hairstyles in the movie. She made sure that the hairstyles that the characters wore were natural or Afrocentric. She is also important to our digital project because she played apart in the postive response the film had on social media considering Black hairstyles were vastly represented.

Ryan Coogler is a motion picture producer and director. He is the director of Black Panther and had a lot of power in terms of the decisions he made to accurately represent Black people. He is signifiant to this digital project because he, like many other Black people, have been longing for a movie that postively represents Black people. This is why he directed the film the way that he did. He is partly responsible for the large amount of Black people taking to digital platforms to voice their attitudes towards the movie which we are very much focused on perserving and amplifying.

Ruth Carter along with Hannah Beachler were costume designers who worked to create the Afrocentric costumes for the Black Panther film. Ruth as a Black woman costume designer was extremely important to the film because she did an amazing job at providing so much representation from multiple African tribes.

Barry Jenkins is a producer and screenwriter. He recently produced the film Moonlight. He alongside other Black filmmakers played an important role in this digital project because they released films that represented Black people in ways that are not common. This caused a lot of Black people to take to social media to talk about these films which we are interested in perserving.

Jordan Peele is an actor, screenwriter, and producer. He recently produced the film, Get Out, which was a box office success to say the least. He is important to this digtial project because he along with other Black screenwriters and producers played a huge part in the vast amount of films released in 2018 that amplified Black people.

Ava DuVernay is a producer, director, and writer. She worked alongside Ryan Coogler as he directed Black Panther and she directed a Wrinkle in Time. She, like Coogler, was responsible for majority of the decisions that went into Black representation in the film. A Wrinkle in Time was another important film of 2018 in it featured quite a few sigficant Black characters played by Stormi Reid, Oprah Winfrey, Conrad Roberts, and David Oyelowo.

body.p: Marvel’s Black Panther is a cultural phenomenon, a historic box office success that’s brought in rave reviews and sparked conversation all over social media and traditional media alike. There are no signs of the excitement abating, either, as the conversation about the film has evolved from discussions about the importance of representation into something grander: a rather groundbreaking celebration of black culture.

With an all-starall star collection of majority blackBlack talent both in front of and behind the camera, Black Panther, under the direction of Ryan Coogler (Fruitvale Station, Creed), is about more than the latest superhero’s journey; it’s also about blackBlack culture’s journey, and it points toward a future where it could be the culture. It acknowledges and celebrates everything from traditional African society to African-AmericanAfrican American political debates, from the power and beauty of blackBlack women to the preservation of identity, all within the lush confines of the fictional African nation of Wakanda.

All told, Black Panther’s greatest legacy may not be what it’s done for Marvel, Hollywood, or box office records, but what it’s done for the culture. In Wakanda, which offers much to marvel at for audiences of all backgrounds, blackBlack viewers in particular have found a cultural oasis that feels like nothing we’ve seen before.
Black Panther celebrates blackBlack culture on several fronts

Black Panther is in many ways a love letter to blackBlack culture. Africa has traditionally been an unsophisticated bit player in American media, often portrayed as backward, savage, and chaotic in everything from news coverage to films. It’s a portrayal that has left little room for other interpretations, which is why Black Panther’s vision of Wakanda as a bustling metropolis of vibranium-poweredvibranium powered futuristic skyscrapers, racing trains, and soaring spaceships feels so refreshing.

Marvel movies often take place in grand, imaginative locales, like Thor’s Asgard or Guardians of the Galaxy’s far-flungfar flung planets. But nothing has been quite as audacious and poignant as Wakanda, a vision of Africa that feels indebted to both Jack Kirby and Octavia Butler, home to a thriving blackBlack population that represents our collective ingenuity and beauty. As a testament to blackBlack empowerment, Black Panther is an important artifact, but it’s also, quite simply, a big draw for blackBlack moviegoers starved for this sort of vision.

It’s not just Wakanda’s skyline that makes an impact, though; the film drew on a team of designers and stylists to showcase a very specific, beautiful blackBlack aesthetic. In an interview with the New York Times, Camille Friend, who oversaw the various hair designs of what she calls “a totally Afrocentric, natural hair movie,” said the entire production was considered against a backdrop of a bigger blackBlack cultural moment: “We’re in a moment when people are feeling empowered about being blackBlack,” she says. “The hair helps communicate that.”

body.p: Like the film’s hair, Black Panther’s costuming was an opportunity to infuse meaning and pride into the movie. As the film’s head costume designer, Ruth Carter, shared with NPR, the costumes, like Wakanda itself, needed to evoke a place and people that had “never been colonized, one that looked toward the future but was based on a real past.”

Carter and her team drew on Kenyan, Namibian, and South African reference points to complete the film’s array of looks, reflecting not only the tribal diversity that exists within Wakanda but the diversity of blackBlack culture and identity as well. The film is a crucial stamp of validation for blackBlack people hungry for the opportunity to celebrate everything from Afrofuturism to the natural hair movement that’s often been derided in mainstream spaces.

The care and intricacy of the film’s styling carried a heavy price tag, with Marvel committing more money to Black Panther than its previous few films in order to achieve a visual splendor that’s as exciting to the culture as it is to the eye. The result is the sort of spectacle blackBlack moviegoers rarely get to see in popular mainstream culture. That isn’t lost on Marvel’s Kevin Feige, who explained his reasoning behind the film’s budget to Vulture: “It’s a big story that deserves to be told in a big way, for all of the cultural and political reasons that people talk about.”

These vague “cultural and political reasons” are at the heart of a movie phenomenon that’s inspired everything from Black Panther-themedPanther themed watch parties to a voter registration initiative to a curriculum that encourages educators to leverage the film to teach deeper histories about African culture, politics, and history. It’s also opened up dialogues and personal reflections about blackBlack identity in America and abroad via #WhatBlackPantherMeansToMe, a powerful cross section of editorial and real-timereal time reflections on the film’s resonance with blackBlack moviegoers.

The film has also jumped into the current of blackBlack political thought and action, prompting challenging think pieces about how T’Challa and Killmonger’s rift is representative of familiar ideological debates in the blackBlack community, and what the film’s politics represent about the state of blackBlack America. In addition to escapism and inspiration, Black Panther offers African Americans the opportunity to reexamine and reimagine their place in the world, both literally and figuratively. Wakanda has emerged as a vision of what’s possible, representing what true liberation could look like, but the power of that fantasy is directly linked to the harsh realities of Erik Killmonger’s experience growing up in Oakland, California, far away from that utopic vision.
Black Panther is part of a wave of entertainment that’s expanding the scope of blackBlack narratives

The excitement around Black Panther doesn’t exist in a vacuum; the film is the latest in a string of high-water-markhigh water mark moments for a blackBlack pop culture landscape that’s experiencing a renaissance. Recent years have seen a new level of blackBlack art that’s intertwined sociopolitical commentary with high-caliberhigh caliber artistry: from Beyoncé’s Lemonade and Kendrick Lamar’s DAMN to Atlanta and Queen Sugar, there’s been a renewed focus on telling stories that broaden and sharpen the range of blackBlack narratives.

This expansion is significant given blackBlack audiences’ complex relationship with Hollywood, which has typically presented a narrow slice of the African-AmericanAfrican American narrative. It’s an industry that has often seemed invested in blackBlack Americans primarily as slaves (12 Years a Slave), victims of inner-cityinner city strife (Detroit), or symbols of comfort (The Help) and is fixated on stories about the post-Reconstructionpost Reconstruction and civil rights eras and biopics of famous blackBlack people that only glimpse at race.

For a long time, it’s felt like the only stories about the African-AmericanAfrican American experience Hollywood was interested in telling were stories that were intertwined in some way with the white experience, making this shift toward stories that center blackBlack narratives as blackBlack narratives feel both welcome and long overdue.

A similar shift has been afoot in Hollywood offscreen in recent years. As #OscarsSoWhite launched a debate about the industry’s fidelity to representation and valuing nonwhite contributions, filmmakers like Moonlight’s Barry Jenkins, A Wrinkle in Time’s Ava DuVernay, and Get Out’s Jordan Peele have taken crucial pole positions as visionaries who are pushing the boundaries of blackBlack representation on film. Coogler’s Black Panther joins these projects as a missing piece: a popcorn movie that uses the most mainstream of film genres — the superhero movie — to project the complexity of blackBlack identity, politics, and creativity.
Black Panther is in many ways an antidote to the blackBlack American experience in 2018

figure.figDesc: This photo is of Michael B. Jordan as Erik Killmonger and Chadwick Boseman as T'Challa in Black Panther.

body.p: The renewed conversation around race that Black Panther enters into extends beyond the entertainment industry. As the first blackBlack superhero film in a cinematic universe that’s spent the past decade focused primarily on white superheroes, it underlines the chasm that exists between society’s treatment of blackBlack Americans and white Americans.

In many ways, blackBlack bodies have experienced a renewed series of attacks in recent years. Black NFL players can’t kneel in protest without recrimination from the president, team owners, or a conservative-leaningconservative leaning fan base. Everyday blackBlack citizens have been increasingly displaced in gentrifying cities, locked up in prisons at alarming rates, and shot and beaten by law enforcement at equally high ones.

This makes Black Panther a palate cleanser of sorts, a healthy injection of powerful, beautiful images of the blackBlack body. It’s what’s behind the lure of Wakanda, a land of blackBlack vibrancy, freedom, diversity, and discourse not blighted by outside forces or forced to negotiate with anyone but themselves. It’s why the Killmonger/T’Challa chasm rings so true, as they both offer their own type of wish fulfillment for blackBlack viewers: Wouldn’t it be nice to have a world where we aren’t encumbered by systemic racism and oppression and are masters of our own destiny? And yet wouldn’t it also be nice to galvanize a community with resources and political might to address and maybe even reverse the effects of that systemic oppression?

Told from a posture of power and pride, Black Panther is in many ways a most necessary antidote for the blackBlack American experience in 2018, an elixir that provides escape into a world where blackBlack Americans can imagine these conversations outside of the white gaze. As blackBlack America feels under assault everywhere from Charlottesville to the White House, it’s invaluable to be reminded that we still have the ability to soar and take action like T’Challa or Nakia or Okoye, to be strong blackBlack bodies of justice. The value of that reminder is not just timely — it’s timeless.
